title: Football: Bulldogs’ Burgess Has Nose For Ball
text:
Football: Bulldogs’ Burgess Has Nose For Ball Football: Bulldogs’ Burgess Has Nose For Ball 
#11 Jax Burgess Special To The Times Record 
GREENWOOD — Jax Burgess gets a lot of attention now from opposing kicking teams. 
Of course, when a player blocks a kick three weeks in a row, it kind of gets the attention of the other team. 
“There is a knack for that,” Greenwood head coach Rick Jones said. “You can coach them, you can teach them, you can walk them through the steps but there’s something about doing it that once they do it they get a feel for it.” 
In the second game of the season, Burgess blocked a field goal attempt by Northside. 
The next week, Burgess blocked another field goal try by Southside. 
In the 7A/6A-Central opener against Van Buren, Burgess blocked a punt and covered it in the end zone for a touchdown. 
“Really, it’s the guys next to me that do a real good job of sealing off the edge,” Burgess said. “It gives me a whole lot better of a chance. If they seal off the edge, I have a clear shot at it. It makes it easier for me, those guys. It’s all about getting a good jump and laying out there and giving it everything you’ve got.” 
It’s a rarity indeed to block kicks in three successive weeks. 
“It’s been my experience that if they do it once, they do it over and over and over,” Jones said. “I was hoping that that was what would happen. Now, he has that confidence. He goes for it and he knows how to do it.” 
Nathan Staton handles the special teams for the Bulldogs, and he planted the idea for Burgess and his special teams’ teammates. 
“Coach Staton does a real good job figuring out the best way to get us clear off the edge,” Burgess said. “We know every week that we have a shot.” 
Opposing teams are now taking steps to prevent it from happening again and even point out where Burgess is lined up. 
“Definitely, they line up a little differently,” Burgess said. “They plan against it. One week, they called me out.” 
Now, of course, the thought of a blocked kick is firmly planted in the other team’s minds. 
“It’s always good to plant the seed,” Jones said. “It’s like going for two (points) on the first touchdown. Now, they have to spend time working on that stuff.” 
Fumbles, interceptions, penalties, they all are big in determining outcomes to games, but it just seems like mistakes in the kicking game are magnified. 
“It’s definitely a mood swinger,” Burgess said. “It gets the momentum going the other way.”
